column4: hey does someone know what i can do to get linux working on a P965 machine?
if Edgy doesn;t work, then complain to Intel about their refusal to supply the FOSS community with worthwhile support.
i'd go bash them with my expensive m/b
it may be the best use yet of that north bridge ;)
because Intel has not given the Linux community what we need to make the 965 work.
this is why i'm an AMD user. i'm tired of Intel's crap.
not much, other than tell Intel you have choices when buying software, and as a Linux user, they are making it hard to choose Intel.
i don;t think you understand
Intel has not supplied the code to make the 965 work in Linux. period. end of story. there is no workaround. there is no magic. there is only "the 965 does not work well with Linux"
some of the 965 pieces work. some do not. the 965 has been nothing but a headache here.
then good luck. i can guarantee the 965 will not be certified for Edgy.

what part of "there is no good support for the 965 in the Linux kernel" is unclear. no one can help you. there is no fix. there is no silver bullet. only Intel has the answers, and they are not sharing.
nothing is unclear
then i'm confused as to why you would say "if anyone has something that could help..."
believe what you want. but our testing has told us the 965 is not ready for Linux.
we have been testing the 965 with Edgy and it is still a giant problem
the. Linux. kernel. does. not. have. good. support. for. the. 965.
Edgy is Linux. we didn;t write a different kernel for this release.

some ports work, some do not. SATA1 is completely broken, SATA2 works fine. the IDE controller works. oh, wait, no it doesn't. now it's back. oops, gone again. oh, there goes SATA2. etc etc etc etc etc etc
so there's general instability?
not instability. outright "IT DOES NOT WORK"
Intel has paid us to certify their hardware, and the 965 is going to fail, fail, fail. period. done. it is not ready for Linux.
